<Summary source="https://www.skyatnightmagazine.com/news/when-will-artemis-ii-launch">
# Summary of BBC Sky at Night Magazine Article on Artemis II Launch Dates

**Publication Date:** February 3, 2026

## Key Facts and Timeline Updates:

**Launch Date Changes:**
- NASA's Artemis II mission will now likely not launch until **March 2026 at the earliest**
- Previous earliest potential launch date of **February 8, 2026** will likely be scrubbed
- Even earlier dates of February 6 and 7 were already scrubbed due to cold weather and winds at Kennedy Space Center
- While February 8 officially remains the earliest launch date as of the article's publication, NASA may announce a delay until March 2026

**Wet Dress Rehearsal Issues (completed February 2, 2026):**
- Delay in fueling due to cold weather
- Liquid hydrogen leak
- 'Retorquing' of a valve associated with pressurization of the Orion crew module capsule
- Dropouts in audio communication affecting ground teams
- The rehearsal took longer than planned due to these issues

**Mission Preparations:**
- Rollout of fully stacked vehicle to Launch Pad 39B completed on **Saturday, January 17, 2026**
- The 4-mile journey from Vehicle Assembly Building took approximately 12 hours
- Wet dress rehearsal included full launch countdown practice and loading over 700,000 gallons of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen

**NASA's Stated Launch Periods through April 2026:**
- January 31 – February 14: Launch opportunities on February 6, 7, 8, 10, and 11
- February 28 – March 13: Launch opportunities on March 6, 7, 8, 9, 11
- March 27 – April 10: Launch opportunities on April 1, 3, 4, 5, 6

**NASA Statement:**
Final timing of the launch will depend on technical readiness and orbital constraints.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.nasa.gov/blogs/missions/2026/02/17/artemis-ii-wet-dress-rehearsal-countdown-begins/">
# Summary of NASA Article on Artemis II Wet Dress Rehearsal

**Date:** February 17, 2026

## Key Facts and Developments:

### Wet Dress Rehearsal Status:
- The countdown for the Artemis II wet dress rehearsal is currently underway at Kennedy Space Center in Florida
- Countdown clock began at 6:50 p.m. EST on Tuesday, February 17, 2026
- Starting point: L-49 hours, 40 minutes before simulated launch window
- Simulated launch window opens: 8:30 p.m., Thursday, February 19, 2026
- Test expected to conclude: approximately 12:30 a.m., Friday, February 20, 2026

### Test Procedures:
The wet dress rehearsal will include:
- Loading cryogenic liquid propellant into the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket's tanks
- Conducting a full launch countdown
- Demonstrating ability to recycle the countdown clock
- Draining tanks to practice scrub procedures
- Testing launch teams at Kennedy Space Center, Mission Control Center at Johnson Space Center, and other NASA centers

### Post-Test Activities:
- After successful completion, teams will install temporary platforms onto the mobile launcher
- Platforms will allow technicians to service flight termination system elements in the solid rocket boosters and core stage
- This testing is required to meet Eastern Range safety requirements

### Launch Timeline:
- **Potential March launch opportunity mentioned** (this is a key update regarding launch timing)
- Official target launch date will be set after the wet dress rehearsal data is reviewed

### Additional Details:
- Artemis II crew members are NOT participating in the wet dress rehearsal
- Artemis closeout crew will practice their operations, including closing the Orion crew module and launch abort system hatches
- NASA is providing 24/7 live stream and real-time blog updates during the test
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.planetary.org/articles/artemis-ii-what-to-expect">
# Summary of "The Artemis II mission: What to expect" from The Planetary Society

## Key Facts and Timeline:

**Launch Dates:**
- Earliest target: March 2026
- Specific dates include: March 6-9, March 11
- Backup opportunities: April 1, April 3-6, and April 30
- Launch location: Kennedy Space Center, Florida, Launch Complex 39B
- A possible February launch was delayed due to a liquid hydrogen leak discovered during a "wet dress rehearsal" (pre-launch test that includes fueling the rocket)

**Mission Details:**
- Duration: Approximately 10 days
- Primary objective: Test flight to demonstrate key systems needed for crewed lunar landing missions
- Systems being tested include: Space Launch System (SLS) rocket, Orion capsule, deep-space life support and environmental controls, crew capsule's heat shield, and communications capabilities

**Crew:**
- Commander Reid Wiseman (NASA)
- Pilot Victor Glover (NASA)
- Mission Specialist Christina Koch (NASA)
- Mission Specialist Jeremy Hansen (Canadian Space Agency)

**Mission Activities:**
- Testing Orion's capabilities in deep space (life-support, environmental systems, manual piloting, communications, navigation)
- Collecting data on human physiology, sleep, motion, and biological responses to space travel
- AVATAR project: using organ-on-a-chip devices to study effects of radiation and microgravity
- Possible geological observations near the Moon to help plan Artemis III

**Context:**
- Artemis I (2022): Successfully sent Orion spacecraft on the same trajectory around the Moon without crew
- Artemis III: Planned for roughly 2028, will be the first crewed Moon landing since Apollo era, targeting lunar south pole for approximately 30-day mission
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.theregister.com/2026/02/16/nasa_has_mixed_results_from/">
# Summary of Article: "NASA has mixed results from a partial fill of Moon rocket"

**Source:** The Register  
**Author:** Richard Speed

## Key Facts and Developments:

**Test Results:**
- NASA conducted a "confidence test" over a weekend involving a partial fill of the Space Launch System (SLS) core stage with liquid oxygen
- The test aimed to check newly replaced seals that had leaked during a recent Wet Dress Rehearsal (WDR)
- NASA stated teams "were able to gain confidence in several key objectives of the test," though results were mixed

**Technical Issues Identified:**
- Reduced flow of liquid hydrogen into the rocket was observed
- Engineers suspect the reduced flow was caused by a filter in ground support equipment
- The filter component has been replaced
- NASA has not confirmed plans for another confidence test before attempting a second WDR in February

**Timeline Information:**
- Artemis II mission is set for launch "in March at the earliest, with additional opportunities in April"
- A second WDR is planned for February

**Official Statements:**
- NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman (via X/Twitter) noted that problems were also observed during the lead-up to Artemis I
- Isaacman stated: "we should not be surprised there are challenges entering the Artemis II campaign" given issues during Artemis I and the long duration between missions
- Isaacman commented on Artemis III: "I will say near-conclusively for Artemis III, we will cryoproof the vehicle before it gets to the pad, and the propellant loading interfaces we are troubleshooting will be redesigned"

**Context Provided:**
- The SLS core stage engines are former Space Shuttle units running on liquid oxygen and hydrogen
- The final Space Shuttle launch was in 2011
- The gap between SLS flights is measured in years rather than months
- Artemis III could "easily slip into the 2030s" unless the mission profile is changed, as it requires a lander that NASA's Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel fears will not be ready in time
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://spaceanddefense.io/early-results-of-artemis-ii-wet-dress-rehearsal/">
# Summary of "Early Results of Artemis II Wet Dress Rehearsal"

**Key Facts and Timeline:**

- **Date of article:** February 3, 2026
- **Current status:** NASA has completed a key fueling test (wet dress rehearsal) of the SLS rocket for Artemis II
- **Rollout date:** SLS rocket and Orion spacecraft were rolled out to Launch Pad 39B on January 17, 2026
- **Test details:** The wet dress rehearsal involves filling the rocket with approximately 700,000 gallons of propellant
- **Test timeline:** "Call to stations" began January 31, with teams counting down toward a simulated launch window that opened at 1:00 pm AEDT on February 3 (9:00 pm EST, February 2)

**Next Steps:**

- NASA will outline early results of the test later in the week (after February 3, 2026)
- Depending on test outcome, the agency may either:
  - Roll SLS and Orion back to the Vehicle Assembly Building for additional work, OR
  - Proceed with final preparations if successful

**Crew Status:**

- The four Artemis II astronauts have been in quarantine in Houston since January 21, 2026
- Crew members: Reid Wiseman (commander), Victor Glover (pilot), Christina Koch (mission specialist), and Jeremy Hansen (mission specialist from Canadian Space Agency)
- If the wet dress rehearsal is successful and they're cleared to travel, astronauts are expected to fly to Kennedy Space Center around 7:00 am AEDT on February 4 (3:00 pm EST, February 3)
- If additional vehicle work is required, crew may remain in Houston or exit quarantine

**Mission Context:**

- Artemis II will be the first crewed mission of NASA's Artemis programme
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.gmtoday.com/news/national/nasa-to-try-artemis-ii-test-run-again-could-set-up-march-moonshot/article_479e941d-635c-4488-b5e6-f39da12aba50.html">
# Summary of Article: "NASA to try Artemis II test run again, could set up March moonshot"

**Source:** Greater Milwaukee Today (via Orlando Sentinel)  
**Date:** February 17, 2026  
**Author:** Richard Tribou

## Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **Wet Dress Rehearsal Schedule:** NASA is planning a second wet dress rehearsal for Thursday night (from context, this would be February 19-20, 2026)

2. **Previous Test Issues:** The first wet dress rehearsal attempt on February 2, 2026 encountered liquid hydrogen (LH2) leaks from ground equipment into the SLS rocket's core stage at Launch Pad 39-B

3. **Historical Context:** Similar leaks occurred during the 2022 Artemis I mission test run and launch

4. **Crew:** Artemis II will carry NASA astronauts Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, Christina Koch, and Canadian Space Agency astronaut Jeremy Hansen

5. **Earliest Launch Date:** March 6 is mentioned as the earliest possible liftoff date (pending successful completion of the wet dress rehearsal)

6. **Mission Duration:** 10-day mission

7. **Propellant Volumes:** The SLS rocket core and upper stages require loading with 700,000 gallons of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen

8. **Recent Technical Work:**
   - Seals were replaced on the connection between ground equipment and rocket
   - A confidence test last week revealed reduced propellant flow
   - A filter in ground equipment was replaced over the weekend

9. **Test Timeline:** Teams called to stations Tuesday night at 6:40 p.m., with full test countdown to T-0 of 8:30 p.m. Thursday, with a four-hour window

10. **Test Duration:** Nearly 50-hour test countdown

11. **Key Test Objective:** A countdown clock reset at T-33 seconds (not performed in the first wet dress rehearsal) is a major task on the to-do list
</Summary>

Query: Will the community prediction be higher than 80.00% on 2026-02-27 for the Metaculus question "Will NASA's Artemis II complete its mission successfully before 2027?"?
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Artemis II: Wet Dress Rehearsal Begins, Final Major Test Before Return to the Moon**
The NASA Wet Dress Rehearsal (WDR) for the Artemis II mission officially began on February 18, 2026, at 00:50 CET (18:50 EST in Florida), marking 'L-49 hours and 40 minutes' before the simulated launch window set for 02:30 CET on Friday, February 20, 2026. The test simulates all launch phases except actual liftoff, with the 'wet' phase involving the loading of cryogenic propellants—liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen—into the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket's tanks at Kennedy Space Center. The exercise includes critical coordination between NASA teams, Houston’s Mission Control, and other strategic centers. Key procedures include preparing temporary platforms for the Flight Termination System (FTS) to meet Eastern Range safety requirements. The countdown uses two timelines: L-time (continuous) and T-time (pausable during 'built-in holds'). During the test, the team will halt T-time at T-1 minute 30 seconds for 3 minutes, resume to T-33 seconds, then reset to T-10 minutes to simulate a technical issue requiring rapid recovery. Although astronauts are not physically on board, their presence is fully simulated, including the closeout crew practicing Orion module and Launch Abort System (LAS) hatch closures with precision. The test is expected to conclude around 06:30 CET on February 20, after which tanks will be drained and data analyzed. A successful test will allow NASA to confirm the official launch date for Artemis II, marking a pivotal step toward humanity’s return to the Moon.
Original language: it
Publish date: February 18, 2026 06:04 AM
Source:[MeteoWeb](https://www.meteoweb.eu/2026/02/artemis-ii-al-via-il-wet-dress-rehearsal-lultima-grande-prova-prima-del-ritorno-verso-la-luna/1001899066/)

**Artemis II: NASA Confirms Start of Final Mission Test to the Moon**
On February 12, 2026, NASA conducted a partial fueling test for the Artemis II mission, during which engineers detected that a ground support equipment filter might be restricting liquid hydrogen flow. The component was replaced over the weekend, the line reconnected, and environmental conditions were restored to resume testing. Based on data from the partial test, engineers deemed it viable to proceed with a full 'wet dress rehearsal' this week. This simulation, known as a wet dress rehearsal, involves loading the rocket with liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen, executing a countdown sequence, and draining the tanks, while also practicing abort procedures to simulate real-world launch suspensions. The countdown will begin at 8:40 p.m. Buenos Aires time on February 17, lasting nearly 50 hours, with the simulated launch scheduled for 10:30 p.m. on February 19, within a four-hour window. During the test, the final ten minutes of the countdown—known as terminal count—will be executed twice: the first time, the countdown will pause at T minus 1 minute and 30 seconds for up to three minutes, then resume until T minus 33 seconds before another pause; the second iteration will restart at T minus 10 minutes to repeat the sequence and advance just before T minus 30 seconds. This procedure allows teams to practice real-time scenarios and abort protocols. The Artemis II crew will not participate in the test, but technical staff will travel to the launch platform to practice closing Orion spacecraft hatches and other operations. The final launch date will not be confirmed until the rehearsal is successfully completed and all data are reviewed. According to current planning, March 6, 2026, is the first viable launch day, allowing time for a second wet dress rehearsal, technical analysis, and final preparations. Artemis II will be NASA’s first crewed mission to the Moon since the Apollo era, orbiting the Moon without landing, serving as a critical precursor to future lunar landing missions.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 17, 2026 09:08 PM
Source:[Todo Noticias](https://tn.com.ar/tecno/novedades/2026/02/17/artemis-ii-la-nasa-confirmo-el-inicio-del-ensayo-final-de-la-mision-a-la-luna/)

**NASA to conduct 2nd rehearsal for possible moon mission this week**
NASA is scheduled to conduct a second wet dress rehearsal for the Artemis II mission on Thursday, February 19, 2026, at the Kennedy Space Center. This full practice launch—without liftoff—will test the systems and procedures required to fuel and launch the 30-story Space Launch System (SLS) rocket with the Orion spacecraft. During the rehearsal, teams will load the rocket with hundreds of thousands of gallons of super-cold liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen, power up both vehicles, and simulate the entire countdown sequence up to just before engine ignition. The first wet dress rehearsal in early February 2026 revealed a liquid hydrogen leak near an umbilical connection, elevated hydrogen gas concentrations, and technical and communication issues during the countdown. Engineers have since replaced seals and filters, adjusted ground support equipment, and refined fueling and countdown procedures. Improvements were also informed by data from the Artemis I mission in 2022, which included five prior wet dress rehearsals. NASA aims to approve Artemis II for launch by March 2026, with the first launch window opening on March 6 and additional windows available in April. If delayed, future opportunities will depend on orbital alignment, with subsequent windows occurring later in the year. Artemis II will be the first crewed mission of NASA’s Artemis program and the first human flight beyond low Earth orbit since the Apollo era, carrying four astronauts on a 10-day journey around the Moon and back.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 17, 2026 05:40 PM
Source:[WRAL](https://www.wral.com/weather/nasa-artemis-ii-wet-dress-rehearsal-feb-2026/)

**NASA teams set for second Artemis II wet dress rehearsal**
NASA is preparing for the second wet dress rehearsal of the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket and Orion spacecraft ahead of the Artemis II test flight, scheduled for Thursday, February 19, 2026, at Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Teams replaced a filter in ground support equipment suspected of restricting liquid hydrogen flow during a partial fueling test on February 12. Engineers used data from that test to plan the full rehearsal, reconnected the liquid hydrogen line with the new filter, and restored required environmental conditions. The rehearsal will simulate a complete launch sequence, including loading cryogenic propellants into the SLS core and upper stage tanks, conducting a full countdown, recycling the countdown clock, and draining tanks to practice scrub procedures. Launch controllers will report to consoles at 6:40 p.m. EST on February 17, initiating a nearly 50-hour countdown. The simulated launch time is set for 8:30 p.m. on February 19, with a four-hour window to accommodate holds. Although the Artemis II crew will not participate directly, a dedicated team will rehearse Orion spacecraft closeout operations, including hatches closure. The rehearsal includes two full terminal count runs: the first pauses at T minus 1 minute 30 seconds for up to three minutes, resumes to T minus 33 seconds, pauses again, then recycles back to T minus 10 minutes to repeat; the second run proceeds to just inside T minus 30 seconds before ending. This allows simulation of real-world launch conditions and responses to scrubs. NASA will not commit to a specific Artemis II launch date until the rehearsal is successfully completed and data reviewed. Mission planners have identified an additional viable launch window in the first week of March, with March 6 now the earliest feasible launch date, allowing time for the rehearsal, data analysis, and transition to launch readiness. A live stream of the SLS and Orion stack is available online, with an additional video feed and status updates via the NASA Artemis blog during fueling day.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 17, 2026 11:21 AM
Source:[SpaceDaily.Com](https://www.spacedaily.com/reports/NASA_teams_set_for_second_Artemis_II_wet_dress_rehearsal_999.html)

**Luna, nuova prova generale per il lancio di Artemis II**
NASA conducted a second 'wet dress rehearsal'—a full-scale simulation of the Artemis II launch—for the upcoming mission that will send four astronauts into lunar orbit. The test, lasting approximately 50 hours, began at midnight on February 18, 2026 (Italian time), with the critical simulation of launch countdown and engine ignition expected at 2:30 AM on February 20, 2026. The test involved loading about 2.65 million liters of propellant into the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket and then safely removing it, while practicing countdown procedures, including simulated aborts and restarts. This follows a previous rehearsal on February 3, 2026, which was delayed due to propellant leakage issues. NASA has since replaced a filter restricting hydrogen flow during a partial fueling test and is working to restore all necessary conditions for the rehearsal. The test, which does not involve actual astronauts, will be simulated by a team of four personnel performing astronaut-like tasks, including closing Orion capsule hatches. Data collected will be analyzed to confirm or adjust the Artemis II launch date, currently set for March 6, 2026. The mission’s success hinges on the results of this final pre-launch simulation.

**NASA Sends Warning to Spain: We Are Not Ready for What Comes in 2026**
The NASA Artemis II mission, scheduled for launch in April 2026 from Kennedy Space Center's Launch Complex 39B in Florida, will be the first crewed flight of the Orion spacecraft and the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket. The mission will carry four astronauts—Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, Christina Koch (NASA), and Jeremy Hansen (CSA)—on a 10-day journey around the Moon, reaching a distance of approximately 370,000 kilometers from Earth and flying 7,400 kilometers beyond the Moon. The mission will test Orion’s life support systems, manual piloting capabilities, and thermal protection during high-speed reentry into Earth’s atmosphere, culminating in a splashdown off the coast of San Diego, California. Scientific payloads will study deep space radiation and human health and behavior. As part of the 'Send Your Name with Artemis' initiative, anyone worldwide can register before January 21, 2026, to have their name stored on a memory chip aboard Orion. Participants receive a digital boarding pass as a keepsake. NASA emphasizes that Artemis II is a critical step toward future crewed missions to the Moon and Mars. The article also claims that Spain is unprepared for what is coming in 2026, though no supporting evidence is provided for this assertion.

**NASA Sets March 6, 2026, as Earliest Launch Date for Artemis II Lunar Mission**
NASA has confirmed March 6, 2026, as the earliest possible launch date for Artemis II, the mission aimed at returning humans to lunar orbit. The mission will carry four astronauts on a 10-day journey around the Moon to test all critical systems. Originally scheduled for February 6, 2026, the launch was postponed to February 8 due to unfavorable weather. Further delays occurred after a liquid hydrogen leak was detected at the interface of the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket’s core stage during a previous wet dress rehearsal. NASA teams replaced a ground support filter that restricted liquid hydrogen flow during refueling, restored proper environmental conditions, and successfully resolved the issue. As of February 19, 2026, NASA plans to conduct the second wet dress rehearsal, involving cryogenic propellant loading, countdown simulation, countdown recycling demonstration, and tank purging to practice cleanup procedures. This rehearsal will guide launch and support teams through key operations ahead of the Artemis II launch.

**NASA Prepares SLS Rocket for Second Full Fueling Ahead of Artemis II Moon Mission**
NASA is preparing for a second full 'wet dress rehearsal' (WDR) of the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket ahead of the Artemis II mission to the Moon. The second attempt, scheduled for 19 February 2026, will involve filling the SLS with over 2.65 million liters of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen to test for leaks and validate system performance. This follows a failed first WDR on 3 February 2026, which was halted at T-5 minutes 15 seconds due to hydrogen leaks exceeding the 16% safety threshold. A previous rehearsal on 12 February tested new seals in the hydrogen fuelling system, but was disrupted by ground equipment issues that slowed hydrogen flow. The upcoming WDR aims to progress the countdown to T-1 minute 30 seconds, pause for 3 minutes, resume to T-33 seconds, pause again, and then return to T-10 minutes for a full simulation. The mission's launch date will be confirmed after a successful WDR, with the earliest possible launch set for 6 March 2026.

**Artemis II: NASA targets Feb. 19 for second moon mission fueling rehearsal**
NASA is targeting Thursday, February 19, 2026, for the second wet dress rehearsal of the Artemis II mission at Kennedy Space Center, marking a critical step toward launching the first crewed lunar mission since the Apollo era. The nearly 50-hour countdown begins at 6:40 p.m. EST on February 17, with a simulated launch window opening at 8:30 p.m. on February 19. The rehearsal includes loading super-cold liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen into the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket, running a full countdown, practicing recycled countdown clocks, and draining tanks—simulating scrub scenarios. Engineers replaced a filter in ground support equipment suspected of restricting liquid hydrogen flow during a partial fueling test on February 12, and enough data was collected to proceed with a full rehearsal. Although astronauts will not participate, ground teams will practice Orion spacecraft closeout procedures, including hatch operations. NASA has not set an official launch date, but March 6 is currently the earliest possible launch opportunity, contingent on a successful test, data review, and transition to launch operations. The rehearsal is one of the final major milestones before flight, designed to simulate real-world launch conditions and identify technical issues before crewed flight. NASA will provide live coverage, including a dedicated camera feed during fueling, and ongoing updates via its Artemis blog. According to NASA, the issue with the hydrogen flow was addressed by replacing the filter and reestablishing proper environmental conditions.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 16, 2026 11:18 PM

**NASA's Latest Attempt to Resolve Moon Rocket's Fueling Problems Didn't Go As Planned**
NASA's recent confidence test to validate repairs on the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket's fueling system encountered issues, casting doubt on its ability to resolve recurring hydrogen leaks ahead of the Artemis 2 launch window in March 2026. The test, conducted on the core stage's liquid hydrogen tank, was only partially successful due to a reduction in hydrogen flow caused by ground support equipment, specifically a suspected faulty filter. Engineers planned to purge the line and inspect the equipment before replacing the filter. The issue stems from a leak detected on February 3, 2026, during a wet dress rehearsal for Artemis 2, which occurred in a tail service mast umbilical on the mobile launcher. Two seals in the mast were replaced in response, but the confidence test did not fully confirm their effectiveness. This problem echoes challenges from the Artemis 1 mission in 2022, where similar leaks caused delays and a scrubbed launch. NASA had used the same loading procedure for Artemis 2 as for Artemis 1, but it failed to prevent the leak this time. NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman acknowledged the challenges, noting that the long gap between missions and prior issues should not be surprising, though he emphasized that safety remains the top priority. 'We will not launch unless we are ready and the safety of our astronauts will remain the highest priority,' Isaacman stated. The Artemis 2 mission is critical as the first crewed lunar mission since Apollo ended in 1972.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 16, 2026 09:00 PM
Source:[Gizmodo](https://gizmodo.com/)

**NASA's Artemis II to launch soon: The moon comeback we've waited 50 years for, explained**
NASA's Artemis II mission, scheduled for launch no earlier than February 2026, marks humanity's first crewed deep space mission beyond low Earth orbit since Apollo 17 in 1972. The 10-day mission will send four astronauts—Commander Reid Wiseman, Pilot Victor Glover (the first Black astronaut to fly to the Moon), Mission Specialist Christina Koch (the first woman to travel to lunar orbit), and Mission Specialist Jeremy Hansen (the first non-American to journey to the Moon)—aboard the Orion spacecraft atop the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket. The mission will perform a lunar flyby using a free-return trajectory, traveling farther from Earth than any previous human mission, and will test critical systems including life-support, navigation, communication, radiation exposure, manual piloting, and re-entry. Unlike Artemis I, which was uncrewed, Artemis II is a high-stakes systems check to validate human capability in deep space before the planned Artemis III lunar landing in 2027. The mission will also conduct biomedical research, deploy CubeSats, capture high-resolution images of the Moon’s far side, and test Orion’s heat shield, which has been re-tuned based on data from Artemis I. Upon completion, Artemis II will serve as the prerequisite for future missions, including Artemis IV, V, and VI, which aim to build the Gateway space station and establish a sustainable lunar presence, with Mars as the ultimate long-term goal. The success of Artemis II is pivotal in proving that humanity remains capable of deep space exploration with confidence and precision.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 23, 2026 12:28 PM
Source:[Mashable ME](https://me.mashable.com/science/66201/nasas-artemis-ii-to-launch-soon-the-moon-comeback-weve-waited-50-years-for-explained)

**Artemis II Set to Launch Human Return to the Moon in February 2026**
After 54 years and $93 billion in investment in space technology, NASA's largest project in history culminates in the return of humans to the Moon. The Artemis II mission is scheduled to launch on February 6, 2026, pending a critical dress rehearsal four days prior to simulate the full countdown and identify potential issues. The Space Launch System (SLS) Block 1, the largest rocket ever built by NASA, successfully completed its rollout on January 17, 2026, after an eight-hour transport to the launch pad at Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral. This marks the final phase of preparations for Artemis II, which will carry four astronauts—three Americans and one Canadian, including a woman—on a 10-day journey beyond the Moon’s orbit, reaching the farthest point ever visited by humans in a crewed mission. Unlike previous Apollo missions, Artemis II does not include a lunar landing module and will not land on the Moon; instead, it is focused on validating crewed flight systems. The first uncrewed test flight of Artemis occurred in 2022. The lunar landing is planned for Artemis III in 2027. The delay in returning to the Moon was due to the end of the Cold War, which removed the political urgency behind the Apollo program. Apollo was driven by geopolitical competition, not long-term exploration. After 1972, funding collapsed, public interest waned, and priorities shifted to cheaper, reusable projects like the Space Shuttle and the International Space Station. Today, the Artemis program is not about prestige but about permanence: establishing infrastructure, testing life-support systems, utilizing lunar resources, and creating a lunar outpost as a staging point for future Mars missions. International partners—including China, India, Japan, Israel, and Europe—and private companies like SpaceX are now key contributors, helping reduce costs and make sustained lunar exploration feasible. NASA aims for a permanent human presence on the Moon by 2030, just four years away.
Original language: pt
Publish date: January 22, 2026 07:07 PM
Source:[Jornal Opção](https://www.jornalopcao.com.br/ultimas-noticias/apos-mais-de-50-anos-artemis-ii-inicia-retorno-humano-em-fevereiro-786387/)

**NASA targets Feb 6 for Artemis II mission**
NASA has targeted February 6, 2026, for the launch of the Artemis II mission, marking the first crewed flight around the Moon since Apollo 17 in December 1972. The 10-day mission will carry four astronauts: NASA commander Reid Wiseman, pilot Victor Glover, mission specialist Christina Koch, and Canadian Space Agency (CSA) astronaut Jeremy Hansen. The Orion spacecraft and Space Launch System (SLS) rocket have been moved to the launch pad at Cape Canaveral, Florida, in preparation. NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman stated that Artemis II will send humans farther from Earth than ever before, providing critical data for future lunar landings and Mars missions. The mission will not land on the Moon but will conduct an initial Earth orbit to test life support and other vital systems. Artemis II will pave the way for Artemis III, scheduled for 2027, which aims to land humans on the lunar South Pole for the first time and establish a sustained presence. This mission is part of NASA’s broader Artemis campaign, focused on scientific discovery, economic benefits, and preparing for future crewed missions to Mars. Artemis I, an uncrewed test flight, was successfully completed in August 2022.

**NASA Moves Artemis II Rocket to Launch Pad: Countdown Begins for Return to the Moon**
NASA has moved the Artemis II rocket, consisting of the Space Launch System (SLS) and the Orion spacecraft, to Launch Pad 39B at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, marking a key step toward the return of humans to the Moon. The transport, conducted at a maximum speed of 1.32 km/h over a distance of more than six kilometers, was completed successfully. The agency will conduct a final dress rehearsal for the mission on February 2, 2026, involving fueling operations, countdown simulations, safe venting of cryogenic propellants, astronaut boarding, and hatch closure. If the test is successful, NASA will hold a flight readiness review to assess all systems, hardware, infrastructure, personnel, launch, and recovery capabilities before setting an official launch date. The Artemis II mission, scheduled to launch no earlier than February 6, 2026, aims to send four astronauts around the Moon to validate all systems ahead of Artemis III, planned for mid-2027. The launch window is subject to four key requirements: successful test completion, availability of essential supplies, favorable weather conditions, and coordination with other users in the Eastern Range. Should technical issues arise, the SLS and Orion could be returned to the Vehicle Assembly Building for additional work. According to NASA, three launch opportunities are currently under evaluation, though delays may occur due to supply chain issues, weather, or scheduling conflicts.

**Lunar Missions, AI Scientists, and Early Cancer Detection: 2026’s Top Science Events**
According to Nature's '2026 Science Events to Watch', major space exploration initiatives are expected in 2026, led by global powers. NASA plans to launch the Artemis II mission in April 2026, sending four astronauts aboard the Orion spacecraft on a lunar orbit mission—marking the first crewed lunar flyby in 50 years since Apollo 17. This follows the uncrewed Artemis I mission completed in late 2024. Success would pave the way for Artemis III, a crewed lunar landing planned for March 2027. China is set to launch the uncrewed Chang'e 7 mission to the Moon’s south pole in August 2026. Japan plans to send a robotic probe to Mars’ moons Phobos and Deimos to collect surface samples. The European Space Agency (ESA) will launch the next-generation exoplanet-hunting space telescope, Plato, by late 2026. On Earth, China will begin deep-sea drilling using its self-developed research vessel 'Mengxiang' to extract mantle samples from up to 11 km below the ocean floor in the Pacific and Indian Oceans, continuing a long-term exploration effort through 2035. This follows a 2023 IODP success that was limited by seawater exposure and funding constraints. In biomedicine, a large-scale clinical trial by Grail (U.S.) and the UK’s NHS will assess the effectiveness of the 'Galleri' blood test, capable of detecting over 50 types of cancer before symptoms appear. The trial involves 140,000 participants, and if successful, FDA approval and clinical use are anticipated. Samsung Electronics and Samsung C&T invested 155 billion KRW in Grail in October 2025 to secure exclusive distribution rights in South Korea. Additionally, Nature predicts a rise in 'AI scientists'—AI agents capable of autonomously conducting research by understanding user intent and executing tasks with minimal human input. South Korea plans to accelerate AI integration in science by developing 'AI research colleagues' and 'AI-specialized foundation models' in key fields like biotech and materials chemistry. However, Nature cautions that AI has already shown serious errors, such as deleting research data, underscoring the need for rigorous validation.

**NASA's Orion Spacecraft Stacked on SLS Rocket for Artemis II Mission**
NASA's Orion spacecraft, named Integrity, was successfully stacked atop the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket on October 19, 2025, at the Kennedy Space Center’s Vehicle Assembly Building in High Bay 3, marking a critical milestone for the Artemis II mission. Lockheed Martin, the prime contractor for Orion, confirmed the integration, noting the spacecraft is the most advanced and human-rated deep-space vehicle ever developed. The Artemis II mission, scheduled for launch no earlier than February 2026 with potential windows extending to April 2026, will carry four astronauts on a 10-day lunar flyby, making it the first crewed lunar mission in over 50 years. NASA Interim Administrator Sean Duffy stated that the SLS-Orion integration represents a major step forward in the Artemis program. Following integration, teams will establish electrical, data, and umbilical connections between Orion and SLS, and the assembled vehicle will be moved to Launch Complex 39B for a full dress rehearsal with propellant loading in the coming year. Lockheed Martin, a major aerospace and defense company with a market cap of €112 billion, reported strong Q3 2025 results: €6.95 EPS (exceeding the consensus of €6.36), €18.6 billion in revenue (slightly above the €18.5 billion forecast), and an operating margin of 12.3%, surpassing analyst projections. Bernstein SocGen Group maintained its 'Market Perform' rating with a €545 target, while Truist Securities reiterated its 'Hold' rating and €500 price target, citing strong earnings and cash flow. The company also announced a €10 million partnership with NioCorp Developments under Title III of the Defense Production Act to develop aluminum-scandium alloys for advanced military aircraft through Lockheed Martin’s Skunk Works division. This collaboration supports U.S. defense innovation and supply chain resilience. Lockheed Martin continues to maintain a 42-year dividend growth streak with a current yield of 2.79% and annual revenue of €71.8 billion.

**Orion Capsule Integrity Mounted on SLS Rocket: Major Milestone for Artemis 2 Mission**
The Orion spacecraft Integrity, designated for NASA's Artemis 2 mission, has been successfully mounted atop the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida, completing the rocket's assembly. This milestone marks a critical step toward the Artemis 2 mission, which is scheduled for a launch window beginning February 5, 2026, and lasting until the end of April 2026. Artemis 2 will be the first crewed mission of the Artemis program, sending four astronauts—Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, and Christina Koch from NASA, and Jeremy Hansen from the Canadian Space Agency—on a 10-day journey around the Moon, including a flyby of the far side, before returning to Earth. The mission follows Artemis 1, an uncrewed test flight launched in November 2022. Despite progress, delays remain a recurring challenge: Artemis 1 and Artemis 2 are separated by over three years due to issues with Orion’s heat shield during reentry. Furthermore, Artemis 3, originally planned for mid-2027, is now projected to launch in 2028, as NASA evaluates alternative options for the lunar lander, particularly due to concerns about SpaceX’s Starship readiness. NASA Acting Administrator Sean Duffy confirmed the completion of the SLS-Orion integration on October 20, 2025, stating on social media: 'We are one step closer to completing the mission!'. The Artemis program aims to establish a sustainable human presence on the Moon and lay the groundwork for future Mars missions.

**NASA is Looking to Launch Artemis II by February**
NASA is preparing to launch the crewed Artemis II mission, the first crewed lunar flight since the Apollo era. The mission is targeted for no sooner than February 5, 2026, and no later than April 2026, and will carry a four‑person crew around the Moon without landing, returning them home ten days later. The Space Launch System (SLS) core and upper stage were stacked between March and May 2025, with the solid rocket boosters completed in February 2025; the Orion spacecraft is in final preparation and will be integrated with the SLS later this year. A wet‑dress rehearsal, where the launch system is fully fueled and a mock countdown is run, will precede the launch. Artemis II will evaluate all systems and architecture that will be used for Artemis III, scheduled for no earlier than mid‑2027. Artemis III will involve a SpaceX‑provided Human Landing System (HLS) that will transfer two astronauts to lunar orbit and descend to the surface, for a mission lasting about 30 days and marking the first Moon walk since Apollo 17 in 1972.

During a meeting on September 19, 2025, members of the Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel (ASAP) expressed doubt that the Starship HLS would be ready in time. Former NASA JSC Mission Operations Director Paul Hill said, 'The HLS schedule is significantly challenged and, in our estimation, could be years late for a 2027 Artemis 3 moon landing.' The panel also noted concerns about the cryogenic propellant transfer that SpaceX must demonstrate, but remained confident in SpaceX’s manufacturing and flight tempo.

NASA announced that the Artemis II crew had named their spacecraft "Integrity". A NASA statement explained, 'The name Integrity embodies the foundation of trust, respect, candor, and humility across the crew and the many engineers, technicians, scientists, planners, and dreamers required for mission success.' The statement also highlighted the effort of more than 300,000 spacecraft components and thousands of people worldwide. During the ASAP meeting, members described the future of NASA’s lunar exploration plans beyond Artemis III as 'uncertain and a little murky.' Despite these concerns, NASA and the Artemis crew are on track to launch Artemis II next year, paving the way for a sustained program of lunar exploration and development.
